title: Uber passenger charged £105 for seven minute journey
text:
The passenger says ‘Uber’s system for complaints is unfair’ following the incident (Picture: SIPA)

An Uber passenger says he has been left ‘shocked’ after receiving a bill of £105 for a seven minute journey.

Mr Oliver Hancock says he received the bill as a ‘cleaning fee’ after leaving a one star rating for an ‘aggressive’ driver, who had shouted at him for putting his plastic carrier bags in the car after a trip to a local supermarket.

Mr Hancock says he quickly moved the three bags and placed them in the boot after the driver’s objection.

After the seven minute journey on Tuesday 15 October from Catford to Hither Green, London, he decided to contact Uber and complain about the driver’s behaviour.

He received a refund for the £5.10 journey.

However, later that same day, he was sent an update to the bill stating there would be a charge of £105 for cleaning services.

Mr Hancock was sent a picture of a wet seat, which Uber is alleged to have claimed came from his journey (Picture: Oliver Hancock)

Mr Hancock told Metro.co.uk: ‘There is no way I was responsible for the damage to the car’.

He was sent two photos by Uber, showing a wet patch on a seat, which he insists ‘was not from his journey’.

He added: ‘I contacted customer services as there was no way I had been responsible for any damage to the car.

‘Three plastic bags on the seat for less than 10 seconds before being placed in the boot?

‘I have retained the bags. The driver gave no indication at the time that a mess was made, and I left the vehicle in the state that I found it.

Mr Hancock says there is no way the damage in the car was from his journey (Picture: Oliver Hancock)

‘I was sent two photos from Uber of the supposed damage I had done, which I believe are fake, from a different incident or were created by the driver in retaliation to the poor review and complaint I made.’

Mr Hancock says the system at Uber is ‘extremely flawed and easily abused’.

He said he totally appreciated that a ‘driver’s car is how they make their money’ and would be ‘happy to pay if he had done any damage’.

Mr Hancock claims that Uber has unfairly sided with the driver, ‘based on two photographs’ and that he has not been provided with any opportunity to refute this.

Could a no-deal Brexit still happen?

He added: ‘Their system does not allow any mitigation, or any response from the customer and only requires a driver to send some photographs through the app in order to pass on an extortionate charge to the customer.’

Advertisement

An Uber spokeswoman said: ‘The Uber app is based on mutual respect for both riders and drivers.

‘For licensed drivers who use the app, their vehicles are their place of work and any damage or mess can mean they are unable to continue working.

‘When a driver claims a cleaning fee, they are required to provide us with the details of the trip, the passengers and the incident itself, as well as photographic evidence and a validated cleaning receipt which our support team then investigates.

‘In this instance, we have refunded the rider. We are constantly evaluating our processes and technology related to these claims and will take appropriate action whenever fraud may be detected.’

description: Mr Oliver Hancock says he received the bill as a ‘cleaning fee’ after leaving a one star review for an ‘aggressive’ driver.
